title: 107_s347
content:
The Act is titled the "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001." It includes reforms to the listing process under the Endangered Species Act of 1973, emphasizing the use of the best scientific and commercial data available. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 by providing definitions and general provisions, emphasizing the use of the best scientific and commercial data available. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 by requiring sufficient biological information to support recovery planning for a species to be classified as endangered or threatened. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" requires sufficient biological information for species to be classified as endangered or threatened under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. Amendments include criteria for listing petitions to add species to the list. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" mandates detailed information on species' range, distribution, population status, threats, and peer-reviewed data in listing petitions for endangered or threatened classification under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" requires listing petitions for endangered or threatened species to include detailed information, peer-reviewed data, and expert opinions not affiliated with the petitioner. If a petition meets the criteria, the Secretary must notify and provide a copy to State agencies where the species is believed to occur. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" mandates agencies to assess if a petitioned action is warranted within 90 days. If no petition is received, the Secretary must notify State agencies when considering listing a species as endangered or threatened. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" requires the Secretary to notify State agencies and consider their assessments before listing a species as endangered or threatened. State assessments must be submitted within a 90-day comment period. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 2001" mandates holding at least 2 hearings in each State where a species is proposed for listing as endangered or threatened, with a minimum of 1 hearing in an affected rural area. The Secretary is not obligated to hold more than 10 hearings per proposed regulation. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to define a rural area as a county or unincorporated area with a population of no more than 10,000 individuals. Additionally, a conforming amendment removes a specific definition from the Act. Emergency listing procedures are also amended. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to define a rural area as a county or unincorporated area with a population of no more than 10,000 individuals. Emergency listing procedures are also amended to make listing data publicly available upon publication of a proposed regulation determining a species as endangered or threatened. The Secretary must disclose all species-related information not supporting a determination, with exceptions for information not required under the Freedom of Information Act or prohibited by the Privacy Act. Criteria for scientific studies to support listing must be established within a year of enactment. The Secretary must establish criteria for scientific and commercial data to support a determination of a species as endangered or threatened. Field data obtained through observation is required for such determinations, including data from landowners. The Secretary must establish criteria for scientific and commercial data to support a determination of a species as endangered or threatened, including field data obtained through observation on land. This data must be included in the rulemaking record for any such determination. SEC. 3. DEADLINE FOR DEVELOPMENT OF RECOVERY PLANS.

The Secretary must begin developing a recovery plan for a species upon proposing a regulation for its protection and issue the final plan when the regulation is finalized.

SEC. 4. DELISTING. Section 4(f) of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include provisions for the change in status of a species from endangered to threatened or vice versa upon meeting recovery plan criteria. The Secretary is required to publish a notice in the Federal Register for any change in status or removal from listing based on the fulfillment of recovery plan criteria. Upon meeting recovery plan criteria, the Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register for the removal of species from the list under subsection (c).
